cards.title:
Wekan Backup:
Atharva, Ayush, Pradeep on point.
Eastern Michigan University partnership and MOU

Phase 6: Documentation and Handover

Document Everything

Write deployment process documentation.
Add troubleshooting steps and common issues.
Handover

Train the team on Kubernetes deployment management.

Phase 5: Integrating with Jenkins

Modify Jenkins Pipeline

Add stages for Docker image build, push, and Kubernetes deployment.
Use kubectl or helm for K8s operations.
Automate CI/CD

Trigger builds on code changes.
Automatically deploy new versions to Kubernetes.

Phase 4: Testing and Debugging

Deploy to Kubernetes

Apply manifests using kubectl.
Verify deployments and services (kubectl get pods/svc).
Testing

Test internal and external connectivity.
Validate ConfigMaps and Secrets.
Logs and Monitoring

Debug using kubectl logs.
Install Prometheus and Grafana for monitoring.

Phase 3: Kubernetes YAML Files

Write Kubernetes Manifests

Define Deployment, Service, StatefulSet, and PVC for all components.
Add readiness and liveness probes.
Configure Networking

Set up Ingress Controller for external access.
Define internal service communication (ClusterIP).
Set Up Namespace and Resource Quotas

Create namespaces for staging/production.
Configure pod resource limits.

Phase 2: Containerization

Containerize Each Component

Create Dockerfiles for Frontend, Backend, Keycloak, PostgreSQL.
Optimize image sizes with multi-stage builds.
Push Images to Container Registry

Use Docker Hub, GitHub, or private registry.
Automate tagging/versioning with Jenkins.
Verify Images

Test services locally using docker-compose or standalone containers.

Phase 1: Planning and Preparation

Understand Application Requirements

Gather component configuration requirements (ports, dependencies, resource limits).
Identify external services (Keycloak, database connections).
Set Up Kubernetes Cluster

Select platform: Minikube (local) or cloud provider (AWS, Azure, GCP).
Configure kubectl and manage contexts.
Define Deployment Strategy

Use Deployment objects for scalable services (Frontend, Backend).
Use StatefulSets for PostgreSQL and Keycloak.
Configure PVCs for database persistence.
Define ConfigMaps and Secrets for environment variables and sensitive data.
Prospective ITSM integration vendors to integrate with
Oracle - incubator and pitchdeck prep
cards.description: Reach out to Tom Plunkett

cards.title: ServiceNow - partnership to be on their marketplace
Develop a set of scripts (Ansible/ etc.) to deploy a new client on a new Rimuhosting instance.
cards.description:
1. Once the instance is spun up, the reach goal is for the script to run the install and the tests to be complete in not more than an hour.
2. This should include:
- creating all servers/ environments
- setting up any metadata
- running a test suite to ensure the environment is appropriately up and running

cards.title: Develop an understanding of the Source of Truth work being done at Mitre
Develop a capability using blockchain to establish SCRM.
Check the JSONs into an ApTSi repo for Wekan
Partnering with Equinix
cards.description:
Phase 1: Planning and Analysis

Understand Business Goals:
Define what partnership with Equinix aims to achieve:
Enhanced availability with Equinix data centers.
Optimized latency for global users.
Integration with Equinix Metal for bare-metal cloud services.
Utilizing Equinix Fabric for interconnection between regions.
Analyze Requirements:
Review the application stack and its deployment requirements (e.g., network latency, storage, compute capacity).
Assess current infrastructure challenges (e.g., downtime, network bottlenecks, regional unavailability).
Engage with Equinix:
Schedule meetings with Equinix representatives to discuss:
Pricing and packages.
Global data center locations and SLAs.
Integration with Kubernetes, Terraform, and other tools.

Phase 2: Define Integration Plan

1. Deployment Architecture:
Global Footprint:
Use Equinix data centers across availability zones for redundancy.
Deploy frontend, backend, and databases in geographically distributed Equinix regions.
Connectivity:
Use Equinix Fabric for secure, high-speed connections between your application regions.
Configure private links to reduce latency and increase security.
2. Kubernetes Deployment on Equinix Metal:
Bare-metal Cloud:
Deploy Kubernetes clusters using Equinix Metal for high-performance workloads.
Use Terraform or Ansible to automate infrastructure provisioning.
Cluster Scaling:
Enable multi-region Kubernetes clusters for cross-zone failover.
Configure network policies for secure communication between clusters.
3. Hybrid Cloud and Interconnect:
Leverage Equinix Interconnect to link with existing cloud providers (Azure, AWS, GCP).
Set up hybrid cloud architecture for workload distribution between on-premises and cloud environments.

Phase 3: Implementation Plan

1. Infrastructure Provisioning:
Equinix Metal:
Set up and provision servers using Equinix Metalâ€™s API.
Use Terraform scripts for automated deployment:
hcl
Copy code
resource "equinix_metal_device" "web_server" {
  hostname         = "web-server-1"
  plan             = "c3.small.x86"
  facilities       = ["sv15"]
  operating_system = "ubuntu_20_04"
}
Network Configuration:
Configure Equinix Fabric for private interconnections.
Set up global load balancing for optimal traffic routing.
2. Application Deployment:
Frontend:
Deploy the Angular and Node applications across multiple Equinix regions.
Use a CDN for faster asset delivery.
Backend:
Deploy Spring Boot services on Kubernetes clusters in Equinix Metal.
Database:
Set up PostgreSQL in active-active replication mode across Equinix regions.
3. Security:
Configure Equinix SmartKey for secure key management.
Use mTLS and certificate-based authentication for intra-cluster communication.

Phase 4: Testing and Validation

Performance Testing:
Test latency, throughput, and connection reliability between regions.
Use tools like Pingdom or Site24x7 to measure user performance.
Resiliency Testing:
Simulate failure of one data center and test failover capabilities.
Use tools like Chaos Mesh for Kubernetes cluster testing.
Monitoring:
Integrate Equinix monitoring tools with your observability stack (Prometheus, Grafana).
Set up alerts for infrastructure and connectivity issues.

Phase 5: Documentation and Collaboration

Document Architecture:
Create diagrams for deployment and network architecture.
Include Terraform scripts, Kubernetes manifests, and network configurations.

cards.title: Obtain sales tool - open source, hosted
Inside sales - cold calling, email follow up
Inside sales - lead generation - friends and known contacts
Develop pitch deck, with pitch for product and by feature

2. These take 3-6 months minimum to get done.
3. Start prevailing art reviews and ACM/ IEEE style position papers (see ACM surveys)
4. They should be followed by content papers.
5. Contribution to OpenGroup reference model

2. The topics should at minimum cover the Products we are building and reference models we are updating (Zero Trust and AI)

cards.title: Assign one blog per feature per employee/ feature owner
Update Website and LinkedIn with Thanksgiving post
Update ApTSi LinkedIn with updates for Houston, DC and upcoming webinar
Update website with KYC for users to login
Update new section with Houston presentation and DC DevOps presentation
Develop videos for each Product Feature

Need some guidance from leadership team on finalizing a secure storage option for encryption keys. 

Currently I am using Hashicorp vault to store encryption keys.
Add LDAP adapter to capture data assets.
Review of PostgreSQL database configuration adapter pending.
Set up a PKI (Public Key Infrastructure) environment between federated adaptive access nodes
Add a feature that allows users to pick the data or fields to be shared between the nodes in JSON format.
The dashboard should direct users to the reporting section.
Add a capability to recommend and auto-generate rulesets and rules based on compliance and other attributes.
Add a capability to show frequently used or favorite rulesets and rules.
11. Tool Like ChatGPT for Asset management.
9. Asset real time status (AM) example Asset is critical or not
Certificate management and mutual TLS should be automated
cards.description:
Phase 1: Planning and Requirements

Identify Certificate Requirements:
Certificates for frontend (Angular/Node) and backend (Spring Boot) services.
Certificates for Keycloak and PostgreSQL for encrypted connections.
mTLS setup for intra-service communication in Kubernetes.
Choose a Certificate Authority (CA):
Use an internal CA (e.g., cert-manager for Kubernetes).
Leverage public CAs (e.g., Let's Encrypt) for external services.
Define Automation Goals:
Automate certificate issuance, renewal, and revocation.
Integrate certificate lifecycle management into the CI/CD pipeline.
Enable dynamic certificate provisioning for mTLS.
Phase 2: Tools and Frameworks Selection
Certificate Management:
cert-manager: Kubernetes-native certificate management for automating CA issuance and renewals.
HashiCorp Vault: For managing secrets, private keys, and certificates securely.
Let's Encrypt: For obtaining publicly trusted certificates automatically.
Mutual TLS:
Use Envoy or Istio as a service mesh to handle mTLS automatically.
Integrate Spring Boot with SSL configurations for mTLS.
CI/CD Integration:
Automate certificate validation, issuance, and deployment using tools like ACME clients or custom Jenkins pipelines.

Phase 3: Implementation Plan

1. Automating Certificate Management
Setup cert-manager:
Deploy cert-manager in the Kubernetes cluster:
bash
Copy code
kubectl apply -f https://github.com/cert-manager/cert-manager/releases/download/v1.13.0/cert-manager.yaml
Create an Issuer for managing certificates:
yaml
Copy code
apiVersion: cert-manager.io/v1
kind: ClusterIssuer
metadata:
  name: letsencrypt-prod
spec:
  acme:
    server: https://acme-v02.api.letsencrypt.org/directory
    email: your-email@example.com
    privateKeySecretRef:
      name: letsencrypt-prod
    solvers:
    - http01:
        ingress:
          class: nginx
Configure services (frontend, backend, Keycloak) with auto-managed certificates.
Renewal Automation:
Use cert-manager to auto-renew certificates before expiry.
2. Mutual TLS (mTLS) Setup
Enable mTLS in Kubernetes:
Create Kubernetes Secrets for storing certificates:
bash
Copy code
kubectl create secret tls service-cert --key=service.key --cert=service.crt
Mount the secret in your pod for secure communication.
Spring Boot Configuration:
Enable mTLS by specifying keystore and truststore in application.properties:
properties
Copy code
server.ssl.key-store=classpath:keystore.jks
server.ssl.key-store-password=changeit
server.ssl.trust-store=classpath:truststore.jks
server.ssl.trust-store-password=changeit
server.ssl.client-auth=need
Service Mesh for mTLS:
Deploy Istio or Linkerd to handle mutual TLS for all intra-cluster communication.

Phase 4: Testing and Validation

Certificate Testing:
Validate certificates using openssl:
bash
Copy code
openssl s_client -connect your-service-url:443
Test renewal and revocation workflows.
mTLS Validation:
Simulate inter-service communication with and without valid certificates.
Use tools like curl with certificates:
bash
Copy code
curl --cert client.crt --key client.key https://your-service-url
Monitoring:
Use Prometheus to monitor certificate expiry dates and mTLS success rates.
Set alerts for impending certificate expirations.

Phase 5: Documentation and Handover

Document Process:
Describe the certificate issuance and renewal process.
Document mTLS configurations for all services.

cards.title: Containerization should be horizontally scalable across PODs and within the POD
cards.description:
Phase 1: Planning and Analysis

Understand Scalability Requirements:
Define the expected workload (number of users, API requests per second, database transactions, etc.).
Identify critical services requiring scalability (e.g., backend services, database read replicas, etc.).
Define Metrics for Autoscaling:
CPU and memory usage thresholds.
API request rates (QPS - Queries Per Second).
Response time SLAs (Service Level Agreements).
Database connection pool size.
Set Goals:
Achieve high availability through redundancy.
Minimize latency under load.
Ensure cost-effective scaling.

Phase 2: Implementation Plan

1. Frontend (Angular + Node):
Horizontal Scalability:
Deploy the Angular application and Node server in separate containers.
Use a Kubernetes Deployment with Horizontal Pod Autoscaler (HPA) based on CPU/memory usage or custom metrics (e.g., API response time).
Serve static assets using a CDN (e.g., Azure CDN or Cloudflare).
Within the POD:
Configure the Node.js process to handle multiple threads using Node.js Cluster or PM2.
Optimize static asset delivery using gzip and caching headers.
2. Backend (Spring Boot):
Horizontal Scalability:
Deploy Spring Boot applications in Kubernetes with replicas.
Use Kubernetes HPA to scale pods based on:
CPU and memory usage.
Custom metrics like request count or response time using Prometheus Adapter.
Within the POD:
Use Tomcat thread pooling to handle concurrent requests efficiently (server.tomcat.max-threads).
Configure connection pool settings in your database driver (e.g., HikariCP):
properties
Copy code
spring.datasource.hikari.maximum-pool-size=50
Implement circuit breakers and rate limiting to manage service overload using Resilience4j or Spring Cloud Circuit Breaker.
3. Database (PostgreSQL):
Horizontal Scalability:
Use read replicas for read-heavy workloads.
Set up a load balancer for distributing read queries across replicas (e.g., Pgpool-II or PgBouncer).
Use partitioning and sharding for very large datasets.
Within the POD:
Optimize query execution with proper indexing and query caching.
Use connection pooling tools like PgBouncer for efficient handling of database connections.
4. Keycloak (Authentication):
Horizontal Scalability:
Deploy Keycloak in a clustered mode using Kubernetes replicas.
Use an external database for Keycloak to ensure session state consistency.
Within the POD:
Enable Keycloak cache (infinispan) to optimize performance.
Use sticky sessions in your load balancer if clustering is enabled.
5. CI/CD (Jenkins):
Horizontal Scalability:
Use Jenkins Distributed Builds with multiple agents/pods for scaling.
Configure Jenkins pipelines to distribute workload dynamically.
6. Kubernetes Infrastructure:
Horizontal Scalability:
Configure HPA at deployment level for all services:
yaml
Copy code
apiVersion: autoscaling/v2
kind: HorizontalPodAutoscaler
metadata:
  name: <service-name>-hpa
spec:
  scaleTargetRef:
    apiVersion: apps/v1
    kind: Deployment
    name: <service-name>
  minReplicas: 2
  maxReplicas: 10
  metrics:
    - type: Resource
      resource:
        name: cpu
        target:
          type: Utilization
          averageUtilization: 70
Use Cluster Autoscaler to scale worker nodes based on resource demand.

Phase 3: Testing and Validation

Stress Test:
Use tools like Apache JMeter, k6, or Locust to simulate high traffic and observe scaling behavior.
Chaos Engineering:
Introduce failures using tools like Chaos Mesh or Gremlin to test resiliency and scaling under stress.
Monitoring:
Use Prometheus and Grafana to monitor pod-level and service-level metrics.
Set up alerts for scaling events and potential bottlenecks.

Phase 4: Documentation and Handover

Document Scaling Strategies:
Include Kubernetes YAML files and HPA configurations.
Document database scaling strategies and Keycloak clustering setup.

cards.title: Security and monitoring posture for each platform and layer should be defined
cards.description:
Phase 1: Planning and Requirements Gathering

Define the Scope:
Platforms: Frontend (Angular + Node), Backend (Spring Boot), Database (PostgreSQL), Authentication (Keycloak), CI/CD (Jenkins), Kubernetes, Infrastructure (Cloud).
Layers: Application layer, network layer, database layer, and infrastructure layer.
Identify Security Standards:
OWASP Security Standards.
Cloud-specific security best practices (e.g., Azure, AWS).
Kubernetes security benchmarks (CIS).
Define Monitoring Needs:
Logs, metrics, traces, and anomaly detection for each layer.
Use observability tools (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana, Loki, Jaeger).

Phase 2: Implementation Plan

1. Frontend (Angular + Node)
Security:
Use Content Security Policy (CSP) to prevent XSS attacks.
Implement Strict Transport Security (HSTS) for HTTPS.
Use Angularâ€™s built-in sanitization to mitigate injection attacks.
Harden API endpoints with rate-limiting and CORS policies.
Monitoring:
Capture application logs using Node.js logging libraries like Winston or Bunyan.
Use browser monitoring tools like Google Lighthouse or integrate OpenTelemetry for frontend tracing.
2. Backend (Spring Boot)
Security:
Implement Authentication using Keycloak (JWT tokens).
Enforce RBAC (Role-Based Access Control).
Use Spring Security for:
CSRF protection.
Input validation and output encoding.
Encrypt sensitive properties in application.yml using Jasypt.
Scan dependencies using OWASP Dependency Check.
Monitoring:
Use Micrometer to expose application metrics.
Configure OpenTelemetry for distributed tracing.
Set up structured logs with Logback.
3. Database (PostgreSQL)
Security:
Enable TLS for Database Connections.
Use row-level security (RLS) for multi-tenant isolation.
Encrypt sensitive data at rest and in transit.
Audit user actions using pgAudit.
Monitoring:
Use pg_stat_statements for query monitoring.
Integrate database metrics with Prometheus.
Set up alerts for replication lag, high query times, and failed login attempts.
4. Authentication (Keycloak)
Security:
Enable Two-Factor Authentication (2FA) for admin users.
Use SSL/TLS for securing Keycloak endpoints.
Regularly rotate client secrets and encryption keys.
Configure IP-based access restrictions.
Monitoring:
Enable Keycloak Event Listener for auditing.
Monitor login failures, token expiration, and session anomalies.
Integrate logs with Loki or a centralized log management system.
5. CI/CD (Jenkins)
Security:
Use Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) for Jenkins users.
Enable HTTPS for Jenkins.
Scan code with SAST tools (PMD, SpotBugs, Checkstyle) and DAST tools (OWASP ZAP).
Secure Jenkins pipelines with secrets management tools like Vault.
Monitoring:
Track pipeline logs and metrics with Prometheus and Grafana.
Monitor build failure trends and pipeline execution times.
6. Kubernetes Infrastructure
Security:
Enable Pod Security Standards (PSS) and apply the least privilege principle.
Use NetworkPolicies to restrict inter-pod communication.
Scan container images for vulnerabilities (e.g., using Grype or Trivy).
Encrypt etcd data at rest.
Monitoring:
Use Kubernetes Dashboard and Prometheus Node Exporter for cluster metrics.
Monitor pod logs with Loki and traces with Jaeger.
Set up alerts for resource overuse, failed deployments, and pod restarts.
7. Cloud Infrastructure
Security:
Implement Identity and Access Management (IAM) roles.
Enable cloud-native firewalls for network security.
Use cloud-native encryption for storage (e.g., Azure Disk Encryption).
Regularly audit infrastructure using CIS Benchmarks.
Monitoring:
Use cloud-native monitoring tools (e.g., Azure Monitor, AWS CloudWatch).
Track infrastructure logs and metrics.

Phase 3: Testing and Validation

Security Testing:
Perform static and dynamic application security testing (SAST, DAST).
Conduct penetration testing for the entire stack.
Test compliance with security standards (e.g., GDPR, HIPAA).
Monitoring Validation:
Simulate failures to validate monitoring alerts.
Verify log, metric, and trace coverage.

Phase 4: Documentation and Handover

Document Security Policies:
Include details for each platform and layer.
Define incident response plans.

cards.title: We should be able to configure on demand and set POD and region specific binding
cards.description:
Phase 1: Planning and Requirement Gathering

Define On-Demand Configuration Needs:
Identify configuration parameters (CPU, memory limits, environment variables, etc.).
Define scalability thresholds (e.g., minimum/maximum replicas, resource usage limits).
Define Pod and Region-Specific Binding Requirements:
Understand how services should bind to specific regions or availability zones.
List region-specific policies (e.g., compliance, latency).
Select Tools for Implementation:
Use Kubernetes features like Horizontal Pod Autoscaler (HPA), Vertical Pod Autoscaler (VPA), Affinity/Anti-Affinity Rules, and Taints and Tolerations.
Use ConfigMaps and Secrets for on-demand configuration.

Phase 2: Implementation

On-Demand Configuration
Parameterize Configurations:
Use ConfigMaps for non-sensitive, environment-specific configurations.
yaml
Copy code
apiVersion: v1
kind: ConfigMap
metadata:
  name: app-config
data:
  ENV: "production"
  MAX_CONNECTIONS: "100"
Use Secrets for sensitive data (e.g., API keys, passwords).
Dynamic Resource Allocation:
Configure HPA for scaling pods based on resource usage:
yaml
Copy code
apiVersion: autoscaling/v2
kind: HorizontalPodAutoscaler
metadata:
  name: app-hpa
spec:
  scaleTargetRef:
    apiVersion: apps/v1
    kind: Deployment
    name: app-deployment
  minReplicas: 2
  maxReplicas: 10
  metrics:
  - type: Resource
    resource:
      name: cpu
      target:
        type: Utilization
        averageUtilization: 70
Enable Vertical Scaling:
Use VPA to adjust resource requests and limits for pods dynamically.
Expose Configuration API:
Provide an interface (e.g., REST API) to update ConfigMaps and Secrets dynamically.
Pod and Region-Specific Binding
Pod Affinity and Anti-Affinity Rules:
Ensure pods are scheduled in specific regions or AZs:
yaml
Copy code
affinity:
  podAffinity:
    requiredDuringSchedulingIgnoredDuringExecution:
    - labelSelector:
        matchExpressions:
        - key: topology.kubernetes.io/region
          operator: In
          values:
          - us-east-1
      topologyKey: topology.kubernetes.io/region
Node Affinity Rules:
Bind pods to nodes in specific regions:
yaml
Copy code
affinity:
  nodeAffinity:
    requiredDuringSchedulingIgnoredDuringExecution:
      nodeSelectorTerms:
      - matchExpressions:
        - key: topology.kubernetes.io/region
          operator: In
          values:
          - us-west-1
Use Taints and Tolerations:
Mark nodes with taints to allow pods with specific tolerations to run on them:
Taint the Node:
bash
Copy code
kubectl taint nodes node1 region=us-east-1:NoSchedule
Pod Toleration:
yaml
Copy code
tolerations:
- key: "region"
  operator: "Equal"
  value: "us-east-1"
  effect: "NoSchedule"
Region-Specific Load Balancing:
Use Ingress with path-based or header-based routing for region-specific traffic.
Deploy region-specific services in tandem with DNS routing (e.g., AWS Route53).

Phase 3: Testing and Validation

Test On-Demand Configuration:
Modify ConfigMaps and Secrets dynamically and validate pod behavior.
Test scaling behavior with different workloads.
Test Pod and Region-Specific Binding:
Deploy workloads in specific regions and validate scheduling.
Simulate region failure and ensure workload redirection.
Observability and Metrics:
Use Prometheus and Grafana to monitor pod distribution, resource usage, and scaling events.

Phase 4: Documentation and Handover

Document Configurations:
Record all ConfigMaps, Secrets, and binding rules.
Include instructions for updating configurations on demand.

cards.title: All components should address cross-availability zones capability
cards.description:
Phase 1: Planning and Architecture Design

Understand Availability Zone Requirements:
Ensure that all critical components (Frontend, Backend, Database, Keycloak, Jenkins) can operate across multiple availability zones.
Identify regional limitations for Kubernetes and cloud services (Azure, AWS, GCP).
Design the Deployment Strategy:
Use Kubernetes features like ReplicaSets, Pod Anti-Affinity, and Node Affinity for distributing workloads.
Ensure storage solutions support AZ replication (e.g., PostgreSQL replication).
Set Up Networking:
Configure a load balancer that supports cross-AZ traffic distribution (e.g., AWS ALB, Azure Application Gateway, GCP Load Balancer).
Ensure DNS routing supports cross-region failover (e.g., using Route53, Traffic Manager).

Phase 2: Implementation

Frontend (Angular + Node.js):
Kubernetes Configuration:
Use Deployments with replicas distributed across AZs.
Configure Ingress with an external load balancer.
Use Node Affinity to ensure pods are deployed across zones:
yaml
Copy code
affinity:
  nodeAffinity:
    requiredDuringSchedulingIgnoredDuringExecution:
      nodeSelectorTerms:
      - matchExpressions:
        - key: topology.kubernetes.io/zone
          operator: In
          values:
          - zone-a
          - zone-b
Load Balancer:
Set up a cloud-native load balancer that distributes traffic across AZs.
Use health checks to remove unhealthy instances.
Backend (Spring Boot):
Kubernetes Configuration:
Similar to Frontend, use Deployments with replicas and anti-affinity rules.
Implement readiness and liveness probes to ensure healthy instances.
Database Connectivity:
Use connection pooling and retries in the backend service to handle AZ failures.
Database (PostgreSQL):
High Availability Setup:
Use a solution like Patroni, CrunchyData, or native PostgreSQL replication for HA.
Configure primary and replicas across AZs.
Persistent Storage:
Use cloud-managed storage solutions with cross-AZ replication (e.g., AWS EBS Multi-AZ, Azure Disk Storage, GCP Persistent Disks).
Authentication (Keycloak):
Clustered Deployment:
Deploy Keycloak in a clustered mode across AZs.
Use a shared database with cross-AZ replication.
Sticky Sessions:
Configure session stickiness if the authentication relies heavily on in-memory state.
HAProxy or Load Balancer:
Use a load balancer to distribute authentication requests across Keycloak nodes.
CI/CD (Jenkins):
Highly Available Jenkins:
Use Jenkins Controller and Agent architecture with multiple agents spread across AZs.
Backup Jenkins configuration and jobs to an external shared storage system.
Distribute Agents:
Configure agents in different AZs to ensure pipeline execution resilience.

Phase 3: Testing and Validation

Simulate Failures:
Test AZ failure scenarios and validate component failover.
Use chaos engineering tools like LitmusChaos to test resilience.
Monitor Traffic and Replication:
Use Prometheus, Grafana, and Jaeger to monitor system behavior under AZ failures.
Ensure database replication is consistent and performant.

Phase 4: Documentation

Document Configuration:
Write detailed guides for deploying and maintaining cross-AZ setups.
Include AZ-specific configurations in your Kubernetes manifests.

cards.title: Containerize the stack using K8
cards.description:
Phase 1: Planning and Preparation

Understand Application Requirements:
Gather configuration requirements for each component (e.g., ports, dependencies, resource limits).
Identify external services (Keycloak, database connections).
Set Up Kubernetes Cluster:
Choose a platform (Minikube for local, cloud provider like Azure, AWS, GCP).
Configure kubectl and context switching for cluster management.
Define the Deployment Strategy:
Use Deployment objects for scalable services (Frontend, Backend).
StatefulSets for PostgreSQL and Keycloak.
PersistentVolumeClaims (PVCs) for database persistence.
ConfigMaps and Secrets for environment variables and sensitive data.

Phase 2: Containerization

Containerize Each Component:
Create Dockerfiles for:
Frontend: Angular + Node.js application.
Backend: Spring Boot (Java Maven).
Keycloak: Use the official Keycloak Docker image.
PostgreSQL: Use the official PostgreSQL Docker image.
Optimize image size using multi-stage builds.
Push Images to Container Registry:
Use Docker Hub, GitHub Container Registry, or a private registry.
Automate image tagging and versioning in Jenkins.
Verify Images:
Test locally with docker-compose or standalone containers to ensure all services run correctly.

Phase 3: Kubernetes YAML Files

Write Kubernetes Manifests:
Frontend:
Deployment + Service (NodePort or Ingress for public access).
Backend:
Deployment + Service (ClusterIP or NodePort).
Database:
StatefulSet + PVC for persistent storage.
Keycloak:
StatefulSet + PVC.
Add readiness and liveness probes.
Configure Networking:
Use Ingress Controller (like Nginx) for external access.
Define internal Service-to-Service communication (ClusterIP).
Set Up Namespace and Resource Quotas:
Create separate namespaces for staging and production environments.
Define resource limits for pods.

Phase 4: Testing and Debugging

Deploy to Kubernetes:
Apply manifests using kubectl apply.
Verify deployments and services using kubectl get pods, kubectl get svc.
Testing:
Check internal and external connectivity.
Ensure ConfigMaps and Secrets are correctly mounted.
Logs and Monitoring:
Use kubectl logs for debugging.
Install monitoring tools (Prometheus, Grafana) for resource usage.

Phase 5: Integrating with Jenkins

Modify Jenkins Pipeline:
Add stages for Docker image building, pushing, and Kubernetes deployment.
Use tools like kubectl and helm for K8s operations.
Automate CI/CD:
Trigger builds on code changes.
Automatically deploy new versions to K8s.

Phase 6: Documentation

Document Everything:
Write detailed documentation for deployment processes.
Add troubleshooting steps and common issues.

cards.title: Infrastructure as code and it should be auditable
We need to have a script or component that takes Wekan (e.g.) and writes it into a github repo
We need a list of what needs to be backed up
Outside sales
cards.description:
1. Outside sales can involve multiple sales channels.
2. We need to track sales by channel and see which resource provided the sale as payments will be to the originating outside sales agent
3. Outside sales - the sales relationship initially will be owned by the originating party. Party gets paid on sales conversion (i.e. on ApTSi receipt of payment for sale).
4. Once converted, ApTSi will retain the relationship.
5. Outside sale margin: outside sales are typically 5% of sale. Any larger sale margin has to be individually negotiated.
6. When setting up the outside sales relationship, we will be doing the following:
 - setting up an MSA
 - setting up individualized sales (this will include leads, contact, customer profile, lead and customer description including pain points and business case for ApTSi)
- individual sales will be by PO and lead realization (conversion and sale)

cards.title: Market segmentation
cards.description:
1. We have 2 segments:
- SMB (50 million or 500 employee or less). Note Cybersecurity can also be driven by customer line of business
- large enterprise

cards.title: Teardown and rebuild
cards.description:
1. Auto generate the data for teardown and rebuild
2. Sensitive data should be synthetic by default. In case we have for a customer reason a need to include PHI, or any sensitive data we need to be able to test for this using annonymization

cards.title: Testing for AI components
cards.description:
1. Based on the type of AI component there are different issues and concerns to be tested for.
2. the framework should auto generate the testing based on the technique used (e.g. test for bias, etc.)
3. Use the ApTSi AI reference model for that purpose

cards.title: AI for testing using adversarial networks
Performance testing
cards.description:
1. Develop a mechanism to define critical workflows. Those are the one's that matter
2. harnesses (autogen) to do the performance test

cards.title: Develop domain language for regression testing
Regression testing:
cards.description:
Regression testing:
- prior data needs to be captured
- there needs to be a model for describing that data
- the defacto regression harness should include prior, current state and diff dirs
- regression test framework should include a configurable digital twin model - you should be able to create a digital twin of the component to be tested, with dummy data, which can be used to generate the test data
- you may need an AI approach to do both the digital twin creation
- try and define a domain model for that too
- the output for a regression test should cover support of existing functionality, target functionality added for the test, and the gaps that don't match.
- The gaps should generate an alert

cards.title: You need to define a domain language to support test cases. Please review prevailing art on the topic and plan to document it
All functional unit tests must be code generated using AI from the textual testcases
Every ApTSi component must be able to support unit testing; Platform centric frameworks capability must be added
Ayush and Pratap are on point
This should be a part of SOASense
All logs must be collatable. Which means that they must have a unique id and correlation attribute
All logs must be encrypted at flight and rest
Every component in the ApTSi platform should emit logs.
cards.description:
It should at least cover:
- Java components
- Web Services
- NodeJs
- Axios
- Angular
- Python
- AI components
- DB
- Deployment components including Terraform, Jenkins, Ansible

cards.title: Hone the tool and train it
Define requirements of platform/tool
cards.description: Tool provides an ability to scan documents/ read assets, convert meeting videos and audios into text; to be able to filter them using small domain models; to allocate into buckets based on prioritization; feed into a decision tree to determine both allocations and prioritization; the rules for the decision tree should use ApTSi frameworks and be configurable; to be able to then generate the architecture documentation (architecture current state) for review by the team and the architect owning the initiative; the tool will use components of AISense and be able to auto-update in the event of changes in the platform architecture. It will be also used to create current/target state documentation and roadmaps. It will be adaptable to other domains and use cases in the future

activities.checklistItemName: Deliver and integrate the final script into the operational workflow.
Make adjustments based on test results.
Test the script on a new "Rimu Host" provisioned for a dummy client.
Add comments within the script for better maintainability.
Create usage documentation for the script:
Ensure modularity for reusable components (e.g., separate database, server, and software setup functions).
Include error-handling logic to ensure graceful failure and rollback.
Add logging mechanisms for better debugging.
Implement a basic smoke test for deployed applications.
Server and database services are running.
Include customizable seeding scripts for client-specific data requirements.
Automate the loading of default seeding data into the database.
Automate the installation of software platforms, including:
Add default configurations for database tuning.
Load database schema and perform migrations (if applicable).
Install and configure web servers (e.g., Nginx/Apache).
Configure basic server settings (hostname, timezone, SSH).
Automate OS installation and configuration (e.g., Ubuntu 22.04 LTS).

Configure network components:
 Firewall rules.
 VPN setup.
 DNS entries.
Set up unique IP allocation for each client instance.
Automate Rimu Host provisioning (e.g., using APIs or CLI tools).
Document the expected input parameters (e.g., client name, instance size, IP).

Specify required tools, libraries, and configurations for:
Servers (e.g., Rimu Host setup).
Database servers (e.g., PostgreSQL).
Network components (firewall, VPN, DNS).
Software (e.g., Keycloak, Java frameworks, Python libraries).
APTSI-specific databases and seeding data.
Define script requirements for automating the setup of independent client instances.
Configure Spring Boot and Keycloak for mTLS

activities.cardTitle:
Phase 6: Documentation and Handover

Document Everything

Write deployment process documentation.
Add troubleshooting steps and common issues.
Handover

Train the team on Kubernetes deployment management.

Phase 5: Integrating with Jenkins

Modify Jenkins Pipeline

Add stages for Docker image build, push, and Kubernetes deployment.
Use kubectl or helm for K8s operations.
Automate CI/CD

Trigger builds on code changes.
Automatically deploy new versions to Kubernetes.

Phase 4: Testing and Debugging

Deploy to Kubernetes

Apply manifests using kubectl.
Verify deployments and services (kubectl get pods/svc).
Testing

Test internal and external connectivity.
Validate ConfigMaps and Secrets.
Logs and Monitoring

Debug using kubectl logs.
Install Prometheus and Grafana for monitoring.

Phase 3: Kubernetes YAML Files

Write Kubernetes Manifests

Define Deployment, Service, StatefulSet, and PVC for all components.
Add readiness and liveness probes.
Configure Networking

Set up Ingress Controller for external access.
Define internal service communication (ClusterIP).
Set Up Namespace and Resource Quotas

Create namespaces for staging/production.
Configure pod resource limits.

Phase 2: Containerization

Containerize Each Component

Create Dockerfiles for Frontend, Backend, Keycloak, PostgreSQL.
Optimize image sizes with multi-stage builds.
Push Images to Container Registry

Use Docker Hub, GitHub, or private registry.
Automate tagging/versioning with Jenkins.
Verify Images

Test services locally using docker-compose or standalone containers.

Understand Application Requirements

Gather component configuration requirements (ports, dependencies, resource limits).
Identify external services (Keycloak, database connections).
Prospective ITSM integration vendors to integrate with
ServiceNow - partnership to be on their marketplace

comments.text:
AI systems learn from new threats and access patterns over time, improving their decision-making capabilities.

Example : An Access attempt flagged as risky might teach the system to recognize similar pattern in future

AI models assign a risk score to access attempts based on contextual data like geolocation, device type, or login patterns.

A low-risk score allows seamless access, whereas a high-risk score could result in additional verification steps.

AI evaluates multiple data points (e.g., time of access, device security posture, and network used) to enforce dynamic access policies.

 E.g Restricting access to critical resources when a user connects via a public Wi-Fi network.

Machine learning models analyze user behavior patterns, such as login times, IP addresses, geolocations, and device usage. Any deviations from the norm trigger adaptive measures.

 If a user suddenly logs in from a new location or device, the system could require multi-factor authentication (MFA) or deny access.

AI algorithms identify abnormal access patterns by comparing current actions to historical data.

E.g A user accessing sensitive data they donâ€™t normally interact with may trigger additional verification or audit logging.

AI converts raw asset metadata from various sources (e.g., CMDB, cloud configurations, syslogs) into a standardized format that aligns with the organization's asset model.

A cloud instanceâ€™s metadata, including its IP, owner, and status, can be normalized to match predefined repository fields like asset_type, asset_location, and asset_status.

LLMs can automatically  suggest access control policies by understanding high-level security requirements and converting them into detailed rules.(Based on getting requirements from the user we can now get the access decision from the to implement into the product).

RAG models can retrieve relevant security information (such as user behavior, threat intelligence, or compliance requirements) from various sources, then use this information to assist in real-time access control decisions.(Subject to adversarial machine learning).
This is the Engine, which explains why the access is not granted to the admin, so he can secure the device thoroughly.

LLMs can assist administrators in creating adaptive access policies based on high-level descriptions in natural language. The LLM can interpret complex access control requirements and convert them into executable rules.
LLMs can automatically generate security and compliance reports, summarizing the security posture of assets, highlighting areas of concern, and recommending actions.

Create the 1 minute teaser videos.

1. Each feature owner to create the content draft
2. Pete and the marketing team will then take the content and draft the video
Develop update of the website with all the prior given list to the Snehals for events and publications. This will start bringing the website upt o date

LLMs can assist administrators in creating adaptive access policies based on high-level descriptions in natural language. The LLM can interpret complex access control requirements and convert them into executable rules.

LLMs can automatically  suggest access control policies by understanding high-level security requirements and converting them into detailed rules.(Based on getting requirements from the user we can now get the access decision from the to implement into the product).

RAG models can retrieve relevant security information (such as user behavior, threat intelligence, or compliance requirements) from various sources, then use this information to assist in real-time access control decisions.(Subject to adversarial machine learning).
This is the Engine, which explains why the access is not granted to the admin, so he can secure the device thoroughly.
LLMs can automatically generate security and compliance reports, summarizing the security posture of assets, highlighting areas of concern, and recommending actions.

AI converts raw asset metadata from various sources (e.g., CMDB, cloud configurations, syslogs) into a standardized format that aligns with the organization's asset model.

A cloud instanceâ€™s metadata, including its IP, owner, and status, can be normalized to match predefined repository fields like asset_type, asset_location, and asset_status.

AI algorithms identify abnormal access patterns by comparing current actions to historical data.

E.g A user accessing sensitive data they donâ€™t normally interact with may trigger additional verification or audit logging.

Machine learning models analyze user behavior patterns, such as login times, IP addresses, geolocations, and device usage. Any deviations from the norm trigger adaptive measures.

 If a user suddenly logs in from a new location or device, the system could require multi-factor authentication (MFA) or deny access.

AI models assign a risk score to access attempts based on contextual data like geolocation, device type, or login patterns.

A low-risk score allows seamless access, whereas a high-risk score could result in additional verification steps.

AI evaluates multiple data points (e.g., time of access, device security posture, and network used) to enforce dynamic access policies.

 E.g Restricting access to critical resources when a user connects via a public Wi-Fi network.

AI systems learn from new threats and access patterns over time, improving their decision-making capabilities.

Example : An Access attempt flagged as risky might teach the system to recognize similar pattern in future

checklists.title: Certificate management and mutual TLS should be automated
Containerization should be horizontally scalable across PODs and within the POD
Security and monitoring posture for each platform and layer
on demand and set POD and region specific binding

checklistItems.title: Define script requirements for automating the setup of independent client instances.

Specify required tools, libraries, and configurations for:
Servers (e.g., Rimu Host setup).
Database servers (e.g., PostgreSQL).
Network components (firewall, VPN, DNS).
Software (e.g., Keycloak, Java frameworks, Python libraries).
APTSI-specific databases and seeding data.
Document the expected input parameters (e.g., client name, instance size, IP).
Automate Rimu Host provisioning (e.g., using APIs or CLI tools).
Set up unique IP allocation for each client instance.

Configure network components:
 Firewall rules.
 VPN setup.
 DNS entries.
Automate OS installation and configuration (e.g., Ubuntu 22.04 LTS).
Configure basic server settings (hostname, timezone, SSH).
Install and configure web servers (e.g., Nginx/Apache).
Load database schema and perform migrations (if applicable).
Add default configurations for database tuning.
Automate the installation of software platforms, including:
Automate the loading of default seeding data into the database.
Include customizable seeding scripts for client-specific data requirements.
Server and database services are running.
Implement a basic smoke test for deployed applications.
Add logging mechanisms for better debugging.
Include error-handling logic to ensure graceful failure and rollback.
Ensure modularity for reusable components (e.g., separate database, server, and software setup functions).
Create usage documentation for the script:
Add comments within the script for better maintainability.
Test the script on a new "Rimu Host" provisioned for a dummy client.
Make adjustments based on test results.
Deliver and integrate the final script into the operational workflow.
Configure Spring Boot and Keycloak for mTLS
Set Up Monitoring for Each Layer
Implement Pod Affinity and Anti-Affinity Rules
Deploy and Test on K8s Cluster

subtaskItems.title:
Understand Application Requirements

Gather component configuration requirements (ports, dependencies, resource limits).
Identify external services (Keycloak, database connections).
